Award.AwardTitle: Improving Undergraduate Engineering Education through Student-Centered, Active and Cooperative Learning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Improving Undergraduate Engineering Education through Student-Centered, Active and Cooperative Learning project at Utah State University involves a multi-fold plan to increase the number, diversity, and quality of engineers entering the workforce. The project will provide four-year scholarships to 26 undergraduate students majoring in Mechanical Engineering, Aerospace Engineering, Civil Engineering, and Environmental Engineering. The project responds to the President's Council on Jobs and Competitiveness' call for more engineers to meet the nation's technological workforce needs. The scholarships will allow talented and financially needy students to reduce the time spent working to cover tuition and expenses and devote time to study and other activities beneficial to students' ability to graduate and enter the engineering profession. To broaden participation, the project will include recruitment through entities which target economically disadvantaged students and underrepresented groups.

Informed by recommendations from the National Research Council's "How People Learn" study, the program will institute learning communities, organized between two departments led by faculty mentors. The program will take advantage of existing student educational support and professional development services including: supplemental instruction (tutoring & peer study groups), undergraduate research, field trips, internships and co-ops, and career counseling. Further, they will increase use of research-proven instructional practices (such as problem-based learning and project-based learning) in several engineering classes to enhance the learning environment for all students, not just program scholars. The program will offer seminars to College of Engineering faculty to promote adoption of research-proven pedagogies and improve teaching and learning in all six College departments. Formative and summative evaluation will be performed by an external evaluator. The project will provide information on program outcomes and lessons learned from the project to the K-16 STEM education community nationwide by dissemination through journals, conferences, and web resources.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Funded by the NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics Program (S-STEM), this project has completed two main tasks.  First, it has provided S-STEM scholarship support for academically-talented, financially-needy students from two largest engineering departments, including the Department of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering (MAE) and the Department of Civil and Environment Engineering (CEE), at Utah State University (USU).  Second, this project has implemented student-centered, active and cooperative learning pedagogy in both curricular and extra-curricular activities.  The purpose was to train S-STEM students to become effective scientific and technological contributors when entering the engineering workforce. 

Scholarship opportunities were advertised in a variety of ways, including sending emails to all MAE and CEE students, posting flyers in the engineering building, and visiting engineering classrooms. The S-STEM Section Committee carefully reviewed each application and selected scholarship recipients based on a comprehensive evaluation of each applicant’s academic merit, professionalism, and unmet financial need.        

Scholarship recipients participated in various project activities, such as orientation, undergraduate research, internships, career counselling, student design competition, industry seminars for professional development, and problem-based and project-based learning in the engineering classroom. Students have made satisfactory progress both academically and professionally. They reported that S-STEM scholarships have helped them reduce their work hours, so they could focus more on their schooling.             

Over the project period, the project staff hosted and delivered S-STEM teaching seminars for faculty members and graduate students in the College of Engineering at USU to promote the adoption of a variety of active learning techniques in the engineering classroom. Seminar attendees provided positive comments on what they had learned from the seminars.       

The project results were disseminated to the STEM education community through a journal publication and conference presentations. For example, the impacts of industry seminars and student design competition, two activities involved in this S-STEM program, were disseminated through a referred journal paper. The results show that these industry seminars increased student understanding of job opportunities as a mechanical, aerospace, civil, or environmental engineer. Student comments on this project were highly positive.  For example, a student commented that “This program has allowed me to fund my education without the need for student loans. I have also been able to get first person feedback and advice from people in the industry through the seminars we had 2-3 times a semester.” Another student commented that “Without it [this S-STEM project], I would not have been able to finish my schooling. This scholarship saved my grades and my sanity. I was able to work fewer hours and focus on my studies more.”
